Parameter description: Sampling frequency
Dependencies: Changing sampling frequency leads to rescaling of some VCP parameters such as TX_AGCT, RX_AGCT, TX_GGWF, TX_NDF1, TX_NDF2, TX_NDF3, UDF. It also affects Equalizer band widths. Make sure that the KAP (DSP library) file used corresponds to the chosen sampling frequency.

Parameter description: Sampling frequency
Dependencies: Changing sampling frequency leads to rescaling of some VCP parameters such as TX_AGCT, RX_AGCT, TX_GGWF, TX_NDF1, TX_NDF2, TX_NDF3, UDF. It also affects Equalizer band widths. Make sure that the KAP (DSP library) file used corresponds to the chosen sampling frequency.

Parameter description: Sampling frequency
Dependencies: Changing sampling frequency leads to rescaling of some VCP parameters such as TX_AGCT, RX_AGCT, TX_GGWF, TX_NDF1, TX_NDF2, TX_NDF3, UDF. It also affects Equalizer band widths. Make sure that the KAP (DSP library) file used corresponds to the chosen sampling frequency.

Parameter description: This setting is used to control minimal allowed user volume. It is requested by VM during DSP initialization process (VM<->DSP message exchange). It does not influence VCP behavior directly.
Dependencies: Effect of setting this parameter fully depends on VM application.

Parameter description: This setting is used to control maximal allowed user volume. It is requested by VM during DSP initialization process (VM<->DSP message exchange). It does not influence VCP behavior directly.
Dependencies: Effect of setting this parameter fully depends on VM application.

Parameter description: Defines static noise reduction gain applied to sub-band signals. The gain is applied to each sub-band when no useful signal is detected in it based on the current amplitude and sub-band noise estimations.
Defines digital gain which is applied on RX output after all processing.
Dependencies: Setting digital gain value higher than 0 dB is highly not recommended

Parameter description: Gain of TXout ‘side-tone’ added to RXout.

Help text: Reference (RXout) to Primary (TXin) delay (bulk delay compensation)
Parameter description: This parameter controls size of delay-line that is used to delay RXout (Reference) or TXin (Primary) signal by n samples. For n > 0 the Reference signal is delayed; for n < 0 the Primary signal is delayed. The parameter is used to compensate for the `bulk` delay present between the channels in the system. If not compensated, delayed Reference signal leads to bad performance of adaptive filters; delayed Primary signal leads to inefficient usage of first filter coefficients.  Properly compensated delay allows to optimize (shorten) adaptive filter length that improves overall performance and reduces computational resources.

Help text: RX output DTGC high-pass filter gain at 1000 Hz in Double Talk
Parameter description: Defines RX signal high-pass filter slope in double talk. Namely, DTGCHP defines attenuation (in dB) at 1000 Hz.

Help text: RX output DTGC attenuated gain hold time
Parameter description: Minimal time (hold time) of RX signal attenuation by DTGC. During this time Rx signal attenuation is constant

Help text: RX output DTGC gain increase time
Parameter description: Defines time that it takes to DTGC to rise loudspeaker gain back to its normal value.

Help text: RX output DTGC gain decrease time
Parameter description: Defines time that it takes to DTGC mechanism to decrease loudspeaker level by ATT dB.

Help text: RX output DTGC attenuation gain in Double Talk
Parameter description: Defines attenuation of the RX signal during double talk. When near speech is detected RX signal is attenuated by this factor.
[TX_AGC]
Dependencies: [TX_AGC]

Parameter description: While AGC input signal level is under this threshold, the signal is considered as noise and AGC gain is not increased.

Help text: Time to double TX AGC gain
Parameter description: [TX_AGCT]
Dependencies: [TX_AGCT]

Help text: Time to double RX AGC gain
Parameter description: [TX_AGCT]
Dependencies: [TX_AGCT]

Help text: RX DRC gain (dynamic range compression factor)
Parameter description: Dynamic Range Compressor operates in two stages. On the first stage it amplifies  the signal by a factor specified as DRC parameter value. Then, if the  amplified signal does not fit the maximal range, it is being limited so that the waveform fits the maximal range and is not clipped (saturated). RX DRC is used to `boost` the level of the signal coming from the network.
RX clipping gain, dB. Rx signals above this level are clipped. This is useful in conjunction with Rx output gain to pump more energy into the speaker signal
Defines maximal allowed AGC gain. Effective AGC gain is always less or equal to this setting.
While AGC input signal level is under this threshold, the signal is considered as noise and AGC gain is not increased.
Defines time that it takes to double AGC gain. I.e. defines how long it takes to AGC to react on (amplify) low-level speech.

Help text: Time to double TX AGC gain
Parameter description: Defines time that it takes to double AGC gain. I.e. defines how long it takes to AGC to react on (amplify) low-level speech.

Help text: TX output 1st DRC (before AGC) saturation threshold
Parameter description: Defines DRC maximal output level. The signal is compressed (gain reduced) to fit into the level defined by this parameter. Signals with amplitude below this threshold (and above the bend point) are passed unaltered. This operation is performed before AGC.

Help text: TX output 2nd DRC (after AGC) saturation threshold
Parameter description: Defines DRC maximal output level. The signal is compressed (gain reduced) to fit into the level defined by this parameter. Signals with amplitude below this threshold (and above the bend point) are passed unaltered. This operation is performed after AGC.
Defines digital gain which is applied on RX input before any processing.
Dependencies: Setting digital gain value higher than 0 dB is highly not recommended

Parameter description: This parameter is allows to scale up the Reference signal (which represents RXout --> AF link) according to the level of acoustic echo present in the TX channel. Reference signal samples are multiplied by 2^REF_SHIFT factor.
[TX_DRC1BEND]
Dependencies: [TX_DRC1BEND]

Parameter description: [TX_NG_NG]
Dependencies: [TX_NG_NG]

Parameter description: [TX_SNS]
Dependencies: [TX_SNS]

Help text: Band noise level threshold for SNS decrease
Parameter description: [TX_BNL]
Dependencies: [TX_BNL]

Parameter description: [TX_SNAT]
Dependencies: [TX_SNAT]

Parameter description: [TX_NTF]
Dependencies: [TX_NTF]

Help text: Band noise level threshold for SNS decrease
Parameter description: BNL controls `noise level dependent noise reduction`. BNL defines a special noise level threshold in each frequency sub-band. If estimated noise level in a sub-band is lower than BNL threshold, then effective noise reduction gain is equal to SNS. If estimated noise level in a sub-band exceeds BNL threshold, then effective noise reduction gain is equal to SNS +(Estimated noise level - BNL)/2, dB.  Consequently, the higher the noise, the greater noise attenuation gain is applied. In any event, applied attenuation cannot exceed SNS + BNL_MING dB. BNL = 0 disables this mechanism, i.e. effective noise reduction gain is equal to SNS. Since BNL is absolute threshold, BNL setting depends on the input signal level.

Estimations of the current noise level are updated constantly during processing in each frequency band. This parameter defines the time that it takes to the algorithm to increase its noise estimations. Smaller values provide faster adaptation to noise level but may decrease stability and cause some voice degradation of continuous, high density speech in noisy conditions.

NTF defines sensitivity of the noise suppressor to fluctuations of sub-band signal amplitude. Lower values increase sensitivity to voice but may lead to false responses causing noise artifacts (e.g. `musical noise`).

Defines location of a bend point on the DRC characteristic. Signal with amplitude below this threshold is attenuated corresponding to the slope of a line connecting between bend point and noise gate point.

Help text: TX output 1st DRC noise gate input level
Parameter description: Signal with amplitude below this threshold is attenuated to NGOL value

Defines the lowest frequency where non-linear distortions of the echo path (RXout -> TXin path) are produced. In frequency bands below NDF1, non-linear distortions of the echo path are considered zero. This parameter generally corresponds to the loudspeaker resonant frequency. Signals with frequencies significantly below the resonant frequency are not reproduced
Dependencies: Affects BCT behavior in frequency bands between NDF1 and NDF3.

Help text: Top frequency producing non-linear distortions (> NDF1)
Parameter description: Defines the highest frequency where non-linear distortions of the echo path (RXout -> TXin path) are produced. Loudspeakers generally produce more distortions at low frequencies (above the resonant frequency).
Dependencies: Affects BCT behavior in frequency bands between NDF1 and NDF3.

Help text: Top non-linear distortions region frequency (> NDF2)
Parameter description: Defines the highest frequency where non-linear distortions of the echo path (RXout -> TXin path) are present. In frequency bands above NDF3, non-linear distortions of the echo path are considered zero.
Dependencies: Affects BCT behavior in frequency bands between NDF1 and NDF3.

Parameter description: NDC purpose is to take into account non-linear distortions present in the echo path (RXout -> TXin path) in BCT calculations. Its value defines `amount of non-linearity` produced by the loudspeaker. More exactly, NDC defines n in BCT formula: (AF_out - n) / AF_in < BCT; where n is a sum of in-band RXout signal amplitudes over bands between NDF1 and NDF2. n is considered 0 in frequency bands below NDF1 and above NDF3. Thus increase of NDC value causes VCP to close bands more frequently in the frequency region between NDF1 and NDF3. NDC = 0 disables the mechanism. Affects BCT behavior in frequency bands between NDF1 and NDF3.

Help text: NDC decrease step in case of Reference signal level decrease
Parameter description: Distortions of the echo path (RXout -> TXin path) that include loudspeaker distortions and non-linear distortions of the system are generally reduced with a decrease in the Reference signal level. NDCS parameter allows optimizing the system performance for different Reference signal levels by defining NDC decrease step when the Reference signal level decreases by 6 dB relative to RSL value. For example, if NDC = 0.9, NDCS = 0.75, RSL=0 then for the reference signal amplitude changing from 0 dB to -6 dB the effective value of NDC will be changing from 0.9 to 0.675 (that is 0.9*0.75=0.675) and so on. This parameter allows to improve double talk performance on low level speaker  signals while retaining good echo suppression on high levels
Dependencies: Affects BCT behavior in frequency bands between NDF1 and NDF3.

Parameter description: With an increase of the Reference (RXout) signal level, sudden and significant increase of the loudspeaker`s distortion and acoustic echo path may occur (e.g. this may correspond to clipping in the power amplifier). RSL defines this level of the Reference (TXout) signal relative to its full digital range. Specifying a non-zero value of RSL allows setting special value of NDC using RSNDC parameter
Dependencies: Affects BCT behavior in frequency bands between NDF1 and NDF3.

Help text: Special NDC value for oversaturated Reference
Parameter description: Defines NDC value for cases when Reference (RXout) signal level exceeds the threshold set by RSL. The following logic is applied: [Reference signal level > RSL] -> [too many distortions appear] -> [NDC should be increased to suppress residual echo without spoiling performance on `normal` signal levels].
Dependencies: Affects BCT behavior in frequency bands between NDF1 and NDF3.

Parameter description: Defines the minimal ratio between in-band signal level after the adaptive filter and signal level before the adaptive filter, when the band is still open. If this ratio is lower than BCT, then sub-band is closed. The following logic is applied: the more significant signal attenuation by the adaptive filter, the higher the probability that this residual signal corresponds to echo; and thus the band can be closed with more confidence. Consequently, larger BCT values cause the algorithm to close bands more frequently. For example, for BCT=-6 dB the sub-band is closed if AF_out / AF_in < 0.5; the sub-band remains open otherwise. BCT mechanism has normally no effect when RX (downlink) signal is not active.

This parameter controls the full-band residual echo suppressor. If the ratio of the sum of the original amplitudes (before the adaptive filter) to the sum of amplitudes in all sub-bands after the adaptive filter and `per band` prior decisions (controlled by Residual Echo Suppressor, in particular BCT) is less than the value specified by GCT, then the full band signal is considered to be a single far talk echo and all bands are closed. I.e. if GCT > sum(sub-band signal amplitudes on ES output) / sum(sub-band signal amplitudes on AF input), the full band signal is considered `echo` and is being closed. Higher GCT values cause the algorithm to close all bands more frequently. For high values of GCT, behavior of the Echo Suppressor becomes close to half-duplex. GCT mechanism has normally no effect when RX (downlink) signal is not active.
Dependencies: In-band signal amplitudes used in GCT ratio calculation are taken with weights defined by GGW and GGWF parameters.

Help text: TX input saturation level (to close ES bands during Far End activity)
Parameter description: Saturation of the TXin (microphone) signal in Double Talk or Single Far Talk is equivalent to non-linear distortions of the echo path leading to possible residual echo passed by the Echo Suppressor. PSL defines a threshold level of the TXin signal level; above this threshold the signal is considered `saturated`. If such saturation occurs during activity on the RXout signal, the full band TX output signal is muted and substituted with comfort noise. PSL has no effect when there is no activity in the downlink channel.

Help text: Defines microphone (ADC) gain of BC5MM using encoded gain setting values from 0 to 15
Parameter description: Defines microphone (ADC) gain of BC5MM. The setting is represented (encoded) by numbers from 0 to 15. The actual gain set on ADC consists of two components: digital ADC gain and analog ADC gain. Gain settings correspond to the following actual ADC gain values (in a format: gain setting - overall gain, dB [digital component / analog component]): 0 - -45 dB [8 / 0]; 1 - -41.5 dB [9 / 0]; 2 - -39 dB [10 / 0]; 3 - -35.5 dB [11 / 0]; 4 - -33 dB [12 / 0]; 5 - -29.5 dB [13 / 0]; 6 - -27 dB [14 / 0]; 7 - -23.5 dB [15 / 0]; 8 - -21 dB [0 / 0]; 9 - -18 dB [0 / 1]; 10 - -15 dB  [0 / 2]; 11 - -12 dB [0 / 3]; 12 - -9 dB [0 / 4]; 13 - -6 dB [0 / 5]; 14 - -3 dB [0 / 6]; 15 - 0 dB [0 / 7]
Dependencies: Effect of setting this parameter fully depends on VM application.

Parameter description: Defines digital gain which is applied after TX input DRC and before AF block.
Dependencies: Setting digital gain value higher than 0 dB is highly not recommended

Parameter description: [TX_BNLEF]
Dependencies: [TX_BNLEF]

Parameter description: [TX_TNAT]
Dependencies: [TX_TNAT]

Parameter description: Defines minimal noise reduction gain addition from BNL mechanism. Overall noise reduction gain in full band never exceeds the follownig value: SNS+BNL_MING+WBNGG.
[TX_WBNG]
Dependencies: [TX_WBNG]

Parameter description: Defines digital gain which is applied on TX output after all processing.
Dependencies: Setting digital gain value higher than 0 dB is highly not recommended

Help text: VCP `test` mode (short periodical beeps on TX and RX); flag
Parameter description: If enabled, short periodical beeps are produced on RX and TX. This feature helps to check whether VCP library is integrated in the system properly or not. The produced tones level is controlled by RX_OG and TX_OG correspondingly.

Help text: VCP `test sound` mode (0 – disable, 1 – TX RX beeps, 2 – sweep tone, 3 – white noise)
Parameter description: If enabled, test sounds are produced on RX and TX. This feature helps to check whether VCP library is integrated in the system properly or not. The produced tones level is controlled by RX_OG and TX_OG correspondingly.

Help text: VCP `test sound` mode (0 – disable, 1 – TX RX beeps, 2 – sweep tone, 3 – white noise)
Parameter description: If enabled, test sounds are produced on RX and TX. This feature helps to check whether VCP library is integrated in the system properly or not. The produced tones level is controlled by RX_OG and TX_OG correspondingly.

Help text: VCP `test sound` mode (0 – disable, 1 – TX RX beeps, 2 – sweep tone, 3 – white noise)
Parameter description: If enabled, test sounds are produced on RX and TX. This feature helps to check whether VCP library is integrated in the system properly or not. The produced tones level is controlled by RX_OG and TX_OG correspondingly.

Help text: VCP `test sound` mode (0 – disable, 1 – TX RX beeps, 2 – sweep tone, 3 – white noise)
Parameter description: If enabled, test sounds are produced on RX and TX. This feature helps to check whether VCP library is integrated in the system properly or not. The produced tones level is controlled by RX_OG and TX_OG correspondingly.
Turns limitation of the ADM output signal on/off.

Help text: Enable Gain Dependent NoiseReduction on TX; flag
Parameter description: Turns AGC gain dependent TX noise suppression on/off. If turned 'on', effective noise suppression gain depends on TX AGC gain (noise suppression gain is decreased proportionally to AGC gain increase).

Help text: Enable Gain Dependent NoiseReduction on RX; flag
Parameter description: Turns AGC gain dependent RX noise suppression on/off. If turned 'on', effective noise suppression gain depends on RX AGC gain (noise suppression gain is decreased proportionally to AGC gain increase).
Flattens the lower part of output noise spectrum (< 600Hz) by applying additional attenuation to low frequencies when a strong low frequency noise is detected.
[TX_NR_LFNF_FLAG]

Help text: Speech Harmonic Enhancement and Restoration (SHER), flag
Parameter description: Enables detection and restoration of low frequency speech harmonics in presence of strong low frequency noise.
[TX_NR_SHER_FLAG]
If enabled, TX input signal is copied to TX output without any processing. In 2mic VCP version, TX input is taken from the microphone choosen  by TX_ADMCNF parameter.
If enabled, RX input signal is copied to RX output without any processing.

Help text: NR, EQ and AGC bypass mode on RX; flag
Parameter description: If enabled, NR, AGC and EQ are not applied to RX
Turns echo suppression on/off

Help text: Set TX/RX digital gains to 1.0 in bypass mode
Use BC5MM internal ADC pre-amp; flag
Parameter description: Enable/disable the use of BC5MM internal ADC pre-amplifier. The pre-amplifier provides 20.5 dB gain increase.
Dependencies: Effect of setting this parameter fully depends on VM application.

Parameter description: Since noise level estimations are independent in frequency bands, applied (effective) noise reduction gain calculated using BNL may differ in different bands.  BNLEF value limits the maximal difference of applied noise reduction gains in bands as follows: max_effective_reduction_gain / min_effective_reduction_gain <= BNLEF. Hence, BNLEF=1 forces applying the same noise reduction gain in all frequency bands, while BNLEF=8 allows up to 8 times (18 dB) difference.
Dependencies: Affects BNL

Parameter description: There is a special mechanism for detection and suppression of fast changing noises. The algorithm estimates noise level changes using combination of wideband signal envelope characteristics and sub-band noise estimations. This mechanism allows shortening noise adaptation time and suppressing transient noises such as sound of passing cars. Adaptation speed of the detector is controlled by TNAT parameter. Setting TNAT=SNAT disables the detector. Setting TNAT < SNAT shortens noise adaptation time for transient noises.
Defines attenuation of noised signal by Wide Band Noise Gate.  This mechanism works with full band signal after synthesis block.
Defines minimal noise reduction gain addition from BNL mechanism. Overall noise reduction gain in full band never exceeds the follownig value: SNS+BNL_MING+WBNGG.

Help text: Defines NDVC volume control mode: 0 - Hardware volume; 1 - Software volume; flag
Parameter description: If the `hardware volume` mode is choosen, the volume in not noisy conditions is defined by the current volume in the system (as reported from VM). RX_NDVCRANGE in this case defines maximal possible automatic volume gain increase. If the `software volume` mode is choosen, the volume in not noisy conditions is set to -RX_NDVCRANGE (dB) in this case defines maximal possible automatic volume gain increase.
Dependencies: Proper NDVC functionality depends on implementation of VM application. In particular, in `hardware volume` mode, VM should set DAC volume according to VM<->DSP message exchange exactly.

Help text: Minimal noise level to react on
Parameter description: Minimal noise level to react on

Help text: Maximal noise level to react on
Parameter description: Defines a noise level that corresponds to the maximal volume gain.
NDVC range (defines maximal allowed automatic gain increase)
Smoothing factor for gain fade-in
Smoothing factor for gain fade-out
Defines steering angle of the ADM preferred direction relative to the line transverse to the axis connecting the two microphones. Relevant for broad-side ADM configuration only.
Dependencies: Applicable in broad-side ADM mode only

Parameter description: Defines ADM configuration: 0 - Far Field (the sound of interest is supposed to be on the axis connecting the two microphones); 1- Near Field (the source of sound is supposed to be close to the front microphone)

Defines ADM configuration: 0 - Far Field (the sound of interest is supposed to be on the axis connecting the two microphones); 1- Near Field (the source of sound is supposed to be close to the front microphone)

Defines ADM configuration: 0 - Far Field (the sound of interest is supposed to be on the axis connecting the two microphones); 1- Near Field (the source of sound is supposed to be close to the front microphone)

Help text: ADM mode: 0-far field, 1-near field, 2-broad side (car), 3-broad side (headset)
Parameter description: Defines ADM configuration: 0 - Far Field (the sound of interest is supposed to be on the axis connecting the two microphones); 1 - Near Field (the source of sound is supposed to be close to the front microphone); 2 – Broad Side (the sound of interest is supposed to be on the line transverse to the axis connecting the two microphones), car mode; 3 - Broad side (the sound of interest is supposed to be on the line transverse to the axis connecting the two microphones), headset mode

Help text: ADM microphone configuration: 0 - dual mic; 1 - first; 2 - second; 3 - difference
Parameter description: ADM configuration: 0 - both microphones are used; 1 - only front mic is used (no beam-forming); 2 - only rear microphone is used (no beam-forming).
Digital gain for the front microphone signal. Applied on the input of ADM block.
Distance between the two microphones
Dependencies: If TX_ADMMODE =  0 (Far Field) or 1 (Near Field), valid range is more narrow: 8…128 mm. Update the distance properly, and beware of possible error messages when switching TX_ADMMODE to or from Far Field modes. You might need to enter a value in range 8...127 prior to changing TX_ADMMODE and only then readjust the ADMDIST value.

Parameter description: Defines whether ADM should consider the microphones reversed or not.

Defines maximal enhancement (compensation) gain applied to the wide-band ADM output signal. For noisy conditions it allows to `recover` voice attenuated mistakenly due to suboptimal sub-band decisions.

Help text: ADM bottom frequency (ADM is disabled below it)
Parameter description: Defines bottom frequency band where ADM processing is performed. ADM is not performed in frequency bands below this frequency (front microphone sub-band signal is used instead).

Defines maximal phase mismatch (degrees) between two microphones. For example, typical phase mismatch of MEMS mics is around 3 deg; ECM mics have potentially greater Defines maximal phase mismatch (degrees) between two microphones. For example, typical phase mismatch of MEMS mics is around 3 deg; ECM mics have potentially greater phase micmatch.
Minimal wind noise reduction gain. This gain is applied to each sub-band when wind noise is detected. Setting this parameter to 0dB disables wind noise reduction
Defines the minimal Non-Linear Processor of ADM block. Smaller gains provide better noise attenuation for the expense of possible speech distortion

Defines signal acceptance angle relative to the ADM axis (sounds coming from angles outside [-ADMMAA, ADMMAA] sector are attenuated). This parameter is relevant for the end-fire (Far Talk) and broad-side configurations only.

Help text: ADM adaptation during Far Talk only; flag
Parameter description: Chooses ADM adaptation mode. If turned `off`, ADM adaptation is performed constantly. If turned `on`, ADM adaptation is performed only when activity on RX output is detected.

Help text: Take into account ADM attenuation in ES; flag
Parameter description: Defines whether ADM signal attenuation is taken into account in ES or not. If turned `on`, BCT estimation looks as follows: AF_out / ADM_in < BCT, i.e. ADM input signal is used in BCT formula instead of AF input signal. The same is relevant for GCT.

Help text: Different polar patern during echo, flag (0-off,1-on)
Parameter description: Forces ADM to have different (separate) polar patterns for cases when echo is present (no RX activity) and when the echo is not present (RX activity detected)
Dependencies: Forced OFF and is not available if the secondary PSKEY is set to zero (0x0000)

Parameter description: In the frequency bands above UDF frequency VCP performs in half-duplex mode - activity of the RXout signal in a sub-band above UDF immediately leads to closing the corresponding sub-band of the TX channel. No adaptive filtering is performed in sub-bands above UDF.
Dependencies: UDF values lower than FSF/2 reduce VCP object size and MIPS consumption, but lead to half-duplex performance in frequency bands above UDF.

Parameter description: Defines duration of a special far-talk time interval that starts immediately after VCP initialization. During this far-talk time interval VCP functions in a pure half-duplex mode. This feature allows VCP to suppress initial echo while adaptive filters have not yet converged.

Help text: Near speech harmonic generation factor (activated in double talk)
Parameter description: Gain of artificially synthesized signal regenerating near speech harmonics in double talk (during RXout signal activity only). Speech regeneration is performed on ES output signal restoring parts of near speech possibly corrupted by the echo suppression mechanism.

Residual echo suppression zeros some (or all) sub-band signals causing changes in the noise spectral properties that can be audible. Comfort Noise Generator compensates for this by injecting artificial, `comfort` noise matching spectral properties of the input noise. This parameter defines gain of artificially generated `comfort noise` substituted instead of echo when the sub-band is closed. The gain is relative to estimated sub-band noise level. Its normal value is 1; but it can be changed for specific cases

Help text: Frequency where GGW factor starts fading
Parameter description: Defines frequency band in which GGW weights fading starts.
Dependencies: Affects GCT behavior.

Parameter description: GGW introduces sub-band weight factors for the signal amplitudes in sums calculated in GCT ratio. Starting at certain frequency (sub-band number) defined by GGWF parameter, the sub-band signal amplitudes are “faded” with the weight factor defined by GGW. This, for example, allows giving the low frequencies greater importance than the high frequencies in GCT. For example, for FSF=8000, with GGW=0.9 and GGWF=1000 Hz, the weights are calculated as follows: for the bands 0-125 Hz, 125-250, ..., 875-1000 Hz the weight is 1.0; for the band 1000-1125 Hz the weight is 0.9; for the band 1125-1250 Hz the weight is  0.9^2; for the band 1250-1375 Hz the weight is 0.9^3  and so on.
Dependencies: Affects GCT behavior.

Help text: The lowest ES output signal allowed when Far End is active
Parameter description: Defines minimal signal level of ES output during RX (downlink) activity. The full band channel is being closed (substituted with comfort noise) automatically if the ES output signal level is below this threshold. This mechanism allows removing low level residual echo splashes. The mechanism is applied after BCT and GCT. For instance, for ESOTHR 0.0078 and 16 bit input PCM samples, the threshold defined by ESOTHR is 0.0078*2^15=256 units.
This parameter allows disabling ES block for RXout signal levels below a threshold. Namely, for RXout signal levels lower than the specified threshold, ES will never close frequency bands.
Dependencies: Affects the whole ES block.

Parameter description: Non-linear distortions of the echo path (RXout -> TXin path) may result not only in transforming energy from one band to another, but also in prolonging the reverberation time. NDCR specifies ‘how long a distortion lasts in time’ producing parasitic frequency components after the initial `excitation`. In other words, for each frame, n in the BCT formula (AF_out - n) / AF_in < BCT is actually calculated as follows: n_effective = max(NDCR*n_prev_frame, n_curr_frame). Therefore, for NDCR=0, the effect of n ends immediately as its excitation on the RXout signal stops (n_effective = n_curr_frame); while for NDCR near (but less than) 1 the effect of n fades-out in time smoothly.
Dependencies: Affects BCT behavior in frequency bands between NDF1 and NDF3.

Help text: Room reverberation time (use only if adaptive filter is not long enough)
Parameter description: Non-zero values enable a special mechanism that takes into account room reverberation time in BCT calculation. RRT defines time (measured in samples) necessary for an echo to decay to -60 dB. For non-zero RRT, BCT is calculated as (AF_out - r) / AF_in < BCT, r is calculated based on estimation of echo attenuation in the environment. Namely, r(n) (which is r on the frame number n) is calculated as r`(n) = max(r(n), C*r(n-1)), where C  is an attenuation coefficient providing attenuation of -60 dB for the given RRT time. RRT-mechanism allows suppressing echo tails lasting longer than adaptive filter length. RRT should be used in cases when echo tail is long, while adaptive filter length is limited and cannot be increased.
Dependencies: Affects BCT behavior.

Help text: Adaptation rate factor for the adaptive filter
Parameter description: Defines adaptation rate factor for the adaptive filter. Higher values provide faster filter convergence, but decrease filter stability.

Help text: Effective length of the adaptive filter
Parameter description: Defines effective length of the adaptive filter.  Longer filter cancels longer echo tail, but leads to slower convergence and increases required computational resources.
Dependencies: For optimal performance, any bulk delay present in the system should be properly compensated by RPD parameter. VCP object size and MIPS consumption are affected by this parameter.

Parameter description: Adaptation of adaptive filters is performed only during Reference signal activity. Enabling this flag extends (holds) the activity by additional 3/4 of the filter length (AFL) after the actual activity ends. This feature usually improves filtering performance.
Turns adaptive filtering on/off. If turned `off`, echo attenuation is not performed (while ES may still perform echo suppression).

Help text: Special NDCNT value for oversaturated Reference during near talk or in unprotected filters mode
Parameter description: If Protected Mode of the adaptive filters is disabled, the parameter defines a special RSNDC value used instead of the original (defined by RSNDC parameter) during periods when near talk is detected. Allows improving duplex performance by having a special `relaxed` RSNDC setting in double talk.Affects BCT behavior in frequency bands between NDF1 and NDF3. If Protected Mode of the adaptive filters is enabled, the parameter defines a special RSNDC value used instead of the original (defined by RSNDC parameter) when adaptive filters are unprotected.

Help text: Global cancellation threshold during near talk or in unprotected filters mode
Parameter description: If Protected Mode of the adaptive filters is disabled, the parameter defines a special GCT value used instead of the original (defined by GCT parameter) during double talk periods (i.e. when near talk is detected). Small residual echo can be masked by near talk. As such this parameter allows improving double talk performance by having a special `relaxed` GCT setting in double talk. If Protected Mode of the adaptive filters is enabled, the parameter defines a special GCT value used instead of the original (defined by GCT parameter) when adaptive filters are unprotected.

Help text: Band cancellation threshold during near talk or in unprotected filters mode
Parameter description: If Protected Mode of the adaptive filters is disabled, the parameter defines a special BCT value used instead of the original (defined by BCT parameter) during double talk periods (i.e. when near talk is detected). Small residual echo can be masked by near talk. As such this parameter allows improving double talk performance by having a special ‘relaxed’ BCT setting in double talk. If Protected Mode of the adaptive filters is enabled, the parameter defines a special BCT value used instead of the original (defined by BCT parameter) when adaptive filters are unprotected.

Help text: Signal level threshold for dynamic management of AF
Parameter description: This parameter relates to VCP Dynamic Processing Management. Adaptation of AF is not performed if Rx output signal level is lower than this threshold. Allows saving processing power.
Dependencies: Affects AF block. Improper setting may spoil echo cancellation performance.

Help text: Signal level threshold for dynamic management of ES
Parameter description: This parameter relates to VCP Dynamic Processing Management. ES block is bypassed if Rx output signal level is lower than this threshold. Allows saving processing power.
Dependencies: Affects ES block. Improper setting may spoil echo cancellation performance.

Help text: Non-linear distortions factor during near talk or in unprotected filters mode
Parameter description: If Protected Mode of the adaptive filters is disabled, the parameter defines a special NDC value used instead of the original (defined by NDC parameter) during double talk periods (when near talk is detected). It allows improving double talk performance by having a special `relaxed` NDC setting in double talk.Affects BCT behavior in frequency bands between NDF1 and NDF3. If Protected Mode of the adaptive filters is enabled, the parameter defines a special NDC value used instead of the original (defined by NDC parameter) when adaptive filters are unprotected.

Help text: Special BCT/GCT/ND settings for case of double talk or unprotected filters mode; flag
Parameter description: Turns on/off the use of BCT_NT/GCT_NT/etc -- a special values for BCT/NDC/etc in double talk (in case Protected Mode is disabled) or unprotected mode of adaptive filters (in case Protected Mode of adaptive filters is enabled). If turned `off`, BCT_NT/GCT_NT/NDC_NT/etc values are ingored.

Help text: Produce beeps when input mic signal exceeds -3 dBFs; flag
Parameter description: If enabled, short beep is produced on RX each time TX input signal exceeds -3 dBFs level. Useful for microphone/ADC signal saturation detection.

Help text: Produce beeps sequence indicating current RX volume setting confirmed by VCP; flag
Parameter description: If enabled, VCP produces beeps sequence on RX every time volume changes. Amount of beeps corresponds to the volume confirmed by VCP to VM.
Disable/enable beeps sequence on reinit (inverted: checkmarked box in config. means that the flag is OFF, so the beeps are enabled; unchecked box means flag ON - beeps disabled)

Turns Reference(RXout)-signal controlled decisions in ES on/off. If turned `on`, ES performs internal decisions about type of talk mode (Far Talk mode, Near Talk mode, Double Talk mode) based on activity detection on RX and TX channels, and can decide to `close` a frequency band irrespective to BCT/GCT estimations. If turned `off`, ES closes bands based on BCT/GCT estimations only, no self-relient decisions are made.
Minimal additional gain applied to suppress frequencies where tones are detected.
Dependencies: Is not available if the secondary PSKEY is set to zero (0x0000)

Parameter description: Minimal additional gain applied to suppress frequencies where tones are detected.
Dependencies: Is not available if the secondary PSKEY is set to zero (0x0000)

Parameter description: Maximal time stretch factor
Dependencies: Is not available if the secondary PSKEY is set to zero (0x0000)

Parameter description: Pitch confirmation time
Dependencies: Is not available if the secondary PSKEY is set to zero (0x0000)

Parameter description: Delay is being accumulated in the channel as a result of speech slowing down. When the accumulated delay reaches the maximal allowed value, speech deceleration gradually stops. In pauses (bewtween phrases and words), the accumulated delay is reduced and the buffer is cleaned.
Dependencies: Is not available if the secondary PSKEY is set to zero (0x0000)

Parameter description: EasyListen voice threshold - signal with level above this threshold is regarded as voice and may be stretched
Dependencies: Is not available if the secondary PSKEY is set to zero (0x0000)

Parameter description: EasyListen noise threshold - signal with level below this threshold, is regarded as noise
Dependencies: Is not available if the secondary PSKEY is set to zero (0x0000)

Parameter description: EasyListen activation flag
Dependencies: Is not available if the secondary PSKEY is set to zero (0x0000)

Parameter description: Defines upper frequency for the protected mode. Adaptive filtering above this frequency is conducted in unprotected mode.
Dependencies: Is not available if the secondary PSKEY is set to zero (0x0000) or any of PM or AF flags is disabled

Parameter description: Defines protected mode threshold for the adaptive filter. Before reaching this level of filtering efficiency the filters work in unprotected mode ensuring the shortest convergence time. After switching to protected regime, the adaptive filters continue soncvergence (including convergence in double talk) although slower than in initial stage. If the required performance of adaptive filters set by this parameter is not observed for some time, the adaptive filters switch to fast convergence (unprotected) mode again.
Dependencies: TX_PMTHR is not available if the secondary PSKEY is set to zero (0x0000) or any of PM or AF flags is disabled

Help text: Time to switch to unprotected mode
Parameter description: If the required performance of adaptive filters set by parameter PMTHR is not observed for some time, the adaptive filters switch to fast  convergence (unprotected) mode again. The time that it takes to switch to unprotected mode is back proportional to ERLIF value set. Set 1.003 (longer time) for stable acoustic conditions (such as in VDA) or 1.01 (faster time) for real conditions.
Dependencies: TX_PMERLIF is not available if the secondary PSKEY is set to zero (0x0000) or any of PM or AF flags is disabled

Help text: TX signal level threshold for DTGC activation
Parameter description: DTGC mechanism can be activated only if the input TX signal level exceeds the threshold defined by DTGCTHR
Dependencies: RX_DTGCTHR is not available if the secondary PSKEY is set to zero (0x0000)

Help text: Minimal VAD value required for AGC activation
Parameter description: AGC gain can be increased only if estimated VAD value exceeds the threshold defined by VADTHR
Dependencies: TX_VADTHR is not available if the secondary PSKEY is set to zero (0x0000)

Help text: Minimal VAD value required for AGC activation
Parameter description: [TX_VADTHR]
Dependencies: RX_VADTHR is not available if the secondary PSKEY is set to zero (0x0000)

Parameter description: Turns adaptive filters protected mode on/off
Dependencies: PM_FLAG is not available if the secondary PSKEY is set to zero (0x0000) or if AF flag is disabled

Help text: Two stage adaptive filtering (0 - one stage, 1 - two stages)
Parameter description: Turns two stage adaptive filtering on/off. If turned 'on', filter adaptation is performed in two stages: at first, first half of the filter coefficients is adapted (1st stage), then full pass is performed for the entire filter
Dependencies: TSF_FLAG is not available if the secondary PSKEY is set to zero (0x0000)

Parameter description: Defines target level for AGC output signal. If the input speech signal is below this level, AGC will raise its gain until the output signal reaches the target level. If the output signal level is above this level (but less than the upper limit), AGC gain will be gradually reduced
[TX_AGCTAR]
Dependencies: [TX_AGCTAR]

Parameter description: Defines the upper limit for the AGC block output signal level. AGC gain is decreased immediately to be below this threshold when output AGC signal exceeds it. The minimal effective AGC gain is 1.
[TX_AGCSAT]
Dependencies: [TX_AGCSAT]

Parameter description: Defines target signal level for signals with level NGIL.
[TX_DRC1NGOL]
Dependencies: [TX_DRC1NGOL]

Parameter description: Turns ADM low frequency region compensation on/off.

Help text: Defines minimal allowed tap signal level for SofTap
Defines SofTap mode (off; mic1 detection; mic2 detection; mic1+mic2 detection)
BC05MM GPIO number used to output digital audio data (Logger PIO)
Parameter description: If LOG_FLAG is enabled, VCP triggers this BC05MM GPIO to output digital audio data. This GPIO should be dedicated for the logging purposes in VM. A special hardware Alango Logger Module is required to capture digital audio logs.
If enabled, VCP triggers  BC05MM GPIO specified by LOG_PIO parameter to output digital audio data.
If enabled, TX OUT digital audio samples are sent to logger GPIO.
Dependencies: Takes effect only when LOG_FLAG is enabled

Parameter description: If enabled, RX OUT digital audio samples are sent to logger GPIO.
Dependencies: Takes effect only when LOG_FLAG is enabled

Parameter description: If enabled, TX1 IN digital audio samples are sent to logger GPIO.
Dependencies: Takes effect only when LOG_FLAG is enabled

Parameter description: If enabled, TX2 IN digital audio samples are sent to logger GPIO.
Dependencies: Takes effect only when LOG_FLAG is enabled

Parameter description: If enabled, RX IN digital audio samples are sent to logger GPIO.
Dependencies: Takes effect only when LOG_FLAG is enabled

Parameter description: A special mechanism that masks annoying sound artifacts (`plops` and clicks) caused by RF lost packets on RX by performing fast and smooth RX signal attenuation within the time of lost packet.

Help text: NR, EQ and AGC bypass mode on RX; flag
Parameter description: If enabled, NR, AGC and EQ are not applied to RX
If enabled, VCP produces beeps in case of DSP overload (when processing is longer than sampling interval).

VCP Configurator stores random number in this PSKEY each time new VCP parameters are applied i.e. written  into the Primary (main) VCP PSKEY. VCP library running inside DSP polls this PSKEY contents each specific time interval. If contents change is detected, VCP re-reads its parameters from the Primary PSKEY and applies them by full re-initialization.

With a valid license key that corresponds to the MAC-address of the device running VCP, VCP operates in a fully functional mode. With a special `demo` license, VCP works in demonstration mode allowing 7 (seven) minutes of normal operation without interruptions; after this period of time RX channel is fully muted. The demo license data for VCP-HF and VCP-HS is shown  in Default Value above:    0123 4567 890A BCDE F012 3456 7890 ABCD . This demo license is valid and can be used only within the following Bluetooth addresses range: 0002 5B 00A5A5 -- 0002 5B 00A5E5 (64 different addresses). If no license is found, or license data is incorrect, VCP produces constant beep via RX channel immediately after the start. If License data consists of 8 zero words, it won't be written into the device (this feature should be used only for the devices with preprogrammed license).

Help text: PSKEY number to store VCP license
Parameter description: VCP looks for its license in this PSKEY. Demo or commercial license is required for proper VCP operation.

PSKEY number to store main VCP parameters in. This number should be specified according to the VM application source code (usually according to `csr_cvc_common_plugin`, `csr_cvc_common_if.h` file). Typical PSKEY numbers for different SDKs are:
Dependencies: If VM application (CVC_plugin) invokes DSP with different PSKEY number, VCP is not able to find/read its parameters and therefore cannot operate properly (such event is indicated by long periodical beeps produced via RX and TX).

Parameter description: Secondary PSKEY is used to store some non-mandatory VCP parameters such as Reference signal EQ. If it is specified as 0x0000, these optional parameters are not stored and their default values are used by VCP. Primary PSKEY contains link to the Secondary PSKEY number.
Dependencies: REF_EQ, BCT_EQ, GCT_EQ and REAR_EQ cannot be set if the secondary PSKEY is set to zero (0x0000)

Help text: Reference signal (RXout -> AF link) EQ coefficients
Parameter description: Defines equalizer settings for the Reference signal input to the Echo Canceller. This EQ is used to compensate  spectral differences of RXout and echo present in TXin (captured by the microphone). For optimal AF performance, these spectral differences shall be minimized.
Dependencies: REF_EQ is not available if the secondary PSKEY is set to zero (0x0000)

Parameter description: Defines equalizer settings for the TX (uplink) signal.
Defines equalizer settings for the RX (downlink) signal.
Defines how fast ADM reacts on changing direction of noise.
Defines how fast ADM reacts on changing direction of echo (during RX activity).
Dependencies: Is not available if the secondary PSKEY is set to zero (0x0000) or TX_ADM_RM_FLAG is disabled

Parameter description: Defines minimal allowed percent of open sub-bands in ES.
Dependencies: This parameter controls a special mechanism that works in parallel to GCT. OBT defines minimal allowed percent of open bands on ES output. If the percent of open bands is lower that this threshold, the whole channel is closed.

Help text: Initial DAC/ADC cbops sync masking time
Parameter description: After opening SCO, CSR DSP framework performs synchronization of DAC/ADC audio buffers (cbops). During this time  (usually up to 5 seconds after SCO opening) the `bulk` system delay (i.e. RXout->TXin delay) may change several times spoiling AEC convergence. This parameter allows to `mask` AEC re-convergence by working in half-duplex mode during the desired initial time.

Help text: Individual BCT settings for each frequency band
Parameter description: Allows to define individual BCT settings for each frequency band.
Dependencies: BCT_EQ is not available if the secondary PSKEY is set to zero (0x0000)

Help text: Allows to set individual band weights for GCT calculation
Parameter description: Allows to set individual/separate band weights for GCT calculation. GCT EQ fully replaces GGW/GGWF frequency bands weighting parametrization.
Dependencies: GCT_EQ is not available if the secondary PSKEY is set to zero (0x0000)

Parameter description: Defines rear microphone eqaulizer coefficients. Used to compensate for frequency response differences between front and rear microphones.
Dependencies: REAR_EQ is not available if the secondary PSKEY is set to zero (0x0000)

Help text: Individual BCT settings for each frequency band; flag
Parameter description: Switches individual BCT settings for each frequency band on and off. BCT EQ is applied only if BCT_EQ_flag is switched on. If it is `off`, BCT EQ is ignored and BCT value is used for all bands.
Dependencies: BCT_EQ is not available if the secondary PSKEY is set to zero (0x0000)

Help text: Allows individual GCT settings for each frequency band; flag
Parameter description: Switches individual GCT settings for each frequency band on and off. GCT EQ is applied only if GCT_EQ_flag is switched on. If it is `off`, GGW/GGWF frequency bands weighting parametrization is applied.
Dependencies: GCT_EQ_flag and GCT_EQ are not available if the secondary PSKEY is set to zero (0x0000)

Help text: Size of acoustic space where acoustic echo is to be cancelled.
Parameter description: This knob defines maximal tail length of acoustic echo to be cancelled. Optimal setting depends on characteristics of echo path and materials.
Dependencies: Affects TX_AFL parameter

Parameter description: This knob controls echo suppression aggressiveness. Depending on characteristics of acoustic echo path (such as signal levels, echo-to-speech level ratio, acoustic absorption of materials, resonances, vibrations, analog/digital signal saturation, etc.) optimal AEC performance may be achieved with different settings. Stronger echo suppression generally leads to less transparent double talk with less echo residues, and vice versa.
Dependencies: Affects TX_BCT, TX_GCT

Help text: Level of noise reduction on TX channel
Parameter description: This knob defines how many noise should be cleaned out from TX signal. Stronger settings generally lead to less noise present in the output signal, but may also result in less natural voice and loss of `presence effect`.
Dependencies: Affects TX_SNS, TX_WBNG

Help text: Level of noise reduction on RX channel
Parameter description: This knob defines how many noise should be cleaned out from RX signal. Stronger settings generally lead to less noise present in the output signal, but may also result in less natural voice and loss of `presence effect`.
Dependencies: Affects RX_SNS, RX_WBNG

Help text: Degree of voice level compensation on TX channel
Parameter description: This knob controls degree of voice level compensation applied to TX signal.
Dependencies: Affects TX_OG, TX_DRC1SAT, TX_AGC, TX_AGCSAT, TX_AGCTAR

Help text: Degree of voice level compensation on RX channel
Parameter description: This knob controls degree of voice level compensation applied to RX signal.
Dependencies: Affects RX_OG, RX_DRCSAT, RX_AGC, RX_AGCSAT, RX_AGCTAR

Parameter description: This knob controls level of DTGC effect (slight attenuation of RX volume when the near-end user is speaking). Stronger settings generally lead to more transparent double talk at expense of more noticable RX voice level decrease in double talk.
Dependencies: Affects RX_DTGC_ATT, RX_DTGCHP

Parameter description: This setting is used to control minimal allowed user volume. It is requested by VM during DSP initialization process (VM<->DSP message exchange). It does not influence VCP behavior directly.
This setting is used to control maximal allowed user volume. It is requested by VM during DSP initialization process (VM<->DSP message exchange). It does not influence VCP behavior directly.

Help text: Use BC5MM internal ADC pre-amp; flag
Parameter description: Enable/disable the use of BC5MM internal ADC pre-amplifier. The pre-amplifier provides 20.5 dB gain increase.

Help text: Defines microphone (ADC) gain of BC5MM using encoded gain setting values from 0 to 15
Parameter description: Defines microphone (ADC) gain of BC5MM. The setting is represented (encoded) by numbers from 0 to 15. The actual gain set on ADC consists of two components: digital ADC gain and analog ADC gain. Gain settings correspond to the following actual ADC gain values (in a format: gain setting - overall gain, dB [digital component / analog component]): 0 - -45 dB [8 / 0]; 1 - -41.5 dB [9 / 0]; 2 - -39 dB [10 / 0]; 3 - -35.5 dB [11 / 0]; 4 - -33 dB [12 / 0]; 5 - -29.5 dB [13 / 0]; 6 - -27 dB [14 / 0]; 7 - -23.5 dB [15 / 0]; 8 - -21 dB [0 / 0]; 9 - -18 dB [0 / 1]; 10 - -15 dB  [0 / 2]; 11 - -12 dB [0 / 3]; 12 - -9 dB [0 / 4]; 13 - -6 dB [0 / 5]; 14 - -3 dB [0 / 6]; 15 - 0 dB [0 / 7]

Help text: Defines output (DAC) gain of BC5MM using encoded gain setting values from 0 to 15
Parameter description: Defines output (DAC) gain of BC5MM. The setting is represented (encoded) by numbers from 0 to 15, each step is 3 dB

Help text: Defines output (DAC) gain of BC5MM using encoded gain setting values from 0 to 15
Parameter description: Defines output (DAC) gain of BC5MM. The setting is represented (encoded) by numbers from 0 to 15, each step is 3 dB

Help text: Defines microphone (ADC) gain of BC5MM using encoded gain setting values from 0 to 15
Parameter description: Defines microphone (ADC) gain of BC5MM. The setting is represented (encoded) by numbers from 0 to 15. The actual gain set on ADC consists of two components: digital ADC gain and analog ADC gain. Gain settings correspond to the following actual ADC gain values (in a format: gain setting - overall gain, dB [digital component / analog component]): 0 - -45 dB [8 / 0]; 1 - -41.5 dB [9 / 0]; 2 - -39 dB [10 / 0]; 3 - -35.5 dB [11 / 0]; 4 - -33 dB [12 / 0]; 5 - -29.5 dB [13 / 0]; 6 - -27 dB [14 / 0]; 7 - -23.5 dB [15 / 0]; 8 - -21 dB [0 / 0]; 9 - -18 dB [0 / 1]; 10 - -15 dB  [0 / 2]; 11 - -12 dB [0 / 3]; 12 - -9 dB [0 / 4]; 13 - -6 dB [0 / 5]; 14 - -3 dB [0 / 6]; 15 - 0 dB [0 / 7]

Help text: Use BC5MM internal ADC pre-amp; flag
Parameter description: Enable/disable the use of BC5MM internal ADC pre-amplifier. The pre-amplifier provides 20.5 dB gain increase.

Help text: Number of parameter set: 0 - main parameter set (when blue led is blinking); 1 - Alternative parameter set (when red led is blinking)
Parameter description: PSKEY number to store main VCP parameters in.
Dependencies: If VM application (CVC_plugin) invokes DSP with different PSKEY number, VCP is not able to find/read its parameters and therefore cannot operate properly (such event is indicated by long periodical beeps produced via RX and TX).

Parameter description: Secondary PSKEY is used to store some non-mandatory VCP parameters such as Reference signal EQ. If it is specified as 0x0000, these optional parameters are not stored and their default values are used by VCP. Primary PSKEY contains link to the Secondary PSKEY number.

VCP Configurator stores random number in this PSKEY each time new VCP parameters are applied i.e. written  into the Primary (main) VCP PSKEY. VCP library running inside DSP polls this PSKEY contents each specific time interval. If contents change is detected, VCP re-reads its parameters from the Primary PSKEY and applies them by full re-initialization.

Help text: PSKEY number to store VCP license
Parameter description: VCP looks for its license in this PSKEY. Demo or commercial license is required for proper VCP operation.

Help text: BC05MM GPIO number used to output digital audio data (Logger PIO)
Parameter description: If LOG_FLAG is enabled, VCP triggers this BC05MM GPIO to output digital audio data. This GPIO should be dedicated for the logging purposes in VM. A special hardware Alango Logger Module is required to capture digital audio logs.
If enabled, VCP triggers  BC05MM GPIO specified by LOG_PIO parameter to output digital audio data.
